longDescription:
Luxor (Ancient Thebes), Egypt Luxor Temple (Egyptian: Ipet resyt, "Southern Sanctuary") is one of ancient Egypt's most magnificent
                temple complexes, dedicated primarily to the Theban Triad of Amun, Mut, and Khonsu. Unlike most Egyptian
                temples dedicated to a cult god or a pharaoh's funerary cult, Luxor Temple was dedicated to the
                rejuvenation of kingship - it was here that many pharaohs were crowned and where the annual Opet
                Festival celebrated the divine union that renewed the pharaoh's power. Located on the east bank of
                the Nile in the heart of modern Luxor, the temple was largely built by Amenhotep III (1390-1352 BCE)
                during the 18th Dynasty, with significant additions by Ramesses II.
name: Luxor Temple
description: Luxor Temple (Ancient Egyptian: Ipet resyt, 'Southern Sanctuary') stands as one of the most magnificent temple complexes of ancient Egypt, dedicated to the rejuvenation of kingship and the Theban Triad of Amun, Mut, and Khonsu. Unlike other Egyptian temples focused on funerary rites or deity worship, Luxor Temple served a unique purpose: it was here that pharaohs were crowned and where their divine ka (spirit) was renewed during the annual Opet Festival. Each year during the Nile flood season, the statue of Amun was carried in a sacred procession from Karnak Temple along a 2.7-kilometer sphinx-lined avenue to Luxor, where the god would unite with his southern form and rejuvenate the pharaoh's divine authority. The temple's core was built by Amenhotep III during the 18th Dynasty (c. 1390-1352 BCE), with Ramesses II adding the massive first pylon, colossal statues, and obelisks (one of which now stands in the Place de la Concorde in Paris). The temple continued to accumulate sacred additions through the Greco-Roman period and later housed a Roman military camp, a Christian church, and the Abu Haggag mosque, which still sits atop ancient ruins - a testament to the site's enduring spiritual significance across cultures and millennia.
